factoid: The countess said 'Yes, Dmítri, clean ones, please.'
The countess sighed deeply.
Dmítri asked the countess 'When would you like them, your excellency?'
Dmítri added 'Allow me to inform you... But, don’t be uneasy.'
Dmítri noticed that the count was beginning to breathe heavily and quickly.
The breathing heavily and quickly of the count was always a sign of approaching anger.
Dmítri said 'I was forgetting... Do you wish it brought at once?'
The countess replied 'Yes, yes; just so! Bring it. Give it to the countess.'
The count said 'What a treasure that Dmítri is' with a smile when Dmítri had departed.
The count said 'There is never any ‘impossible’ with him.'
The count said 'That’s a thing I hate! Everything is possible.'
The countess said 'Ah, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world.'
The countess said 'But I am in great need of this sum.'
The count said 'You, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift.'
The count kissed the countess’s hand and went back to his study.
Anna Mikháylovna returned from Count Bezúkhov’s house with money.
The money was all in clean notes.
The money was lying ready under a handkerchief on the countess' little table.
Anna Mikháylovna noticed that something was agitating her.
The countess began to speak with a blush that looked very strange on her thin, dignified, elderly face.
The countess took the money from under the handkerchief.
Anna Mikháylovna instantly guessed the countess's intention.
Anna Mikháylovna stooped to be ready to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.
Anna Mikháylovna said 'This is for Borís from me, for his outfit.'
Anna Mikháylovna was embracing the countess and weeping.
The countess wept too.
They wept because they were friends.
They wept because they were kindhearted.
They wept because they were friends from childhood.
They wept because they had to think about such a base thing as money.
They wept because their youth was over.
The tears were pleasant to them both.
Countess Rostóva was seated in the drawing room with her daughters and a large number of guests.
The count took the gentlemen into his study.
The count showed the gentlemen his choice collection of Turkish pipes.
The count went out from his study to ask 'Hasn’t she come yet?'.
They were expecting Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova.
Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova was known in society as le terrible dragon.
Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova was a lady distinguished not for wealth or rank, but for common sense and frank plainness of speech.
Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova was known to the Imperial family.
Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova was known to all Moscow.
Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova was known to all Petersburg.
Both Moscow and Petersburg wondered at Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova.
Both Moscow and Petersburg laughed privately at Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova's rudenesses.
Both Moscow and Petersburg told good stories about Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova.
All people respected and feared Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova.
In the count's room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked about the war that had been announced in a manifesto.
In the count's room, they talked about recruiting.
None of them had yet seen the manifesto.
They all knew the manifesto had appeared.
The count sat on the sofa between two guests.
The two guests were smoking and talking.
The count neither smoked nor talked.
The count bent his head first to one side and then to the other.
The count watched the smokers with evident pleasure.
The count listened to the conversation of his two neighbors.
The count egged his two neighbors against each other.
